questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used during day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Drugs that can be used for daycare surgery are:
Dr → Desflurane
Manmohan → Midazolam
Singh → Sevoflurane
Is → Isoflurane
A → Alfentanil
Prime → Propofol
Minister → Mivacurium

questions.text: Which of the following would be the cause of generalized convulsions 20 minutes postoperatively?
questions.solution: • Enflurane causes generalized convulsions, within 20-30 minutes postoperatively.

questions.text: A 69 year old male presented to the ER complaining that he was experiencing the worst headache of his life. What would be the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in this patient?
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis:Subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Subarachnoid haemorrhage

  • IOC for initial diagnosis:computed tomography (CT) of the head without intravenous (IV) contrast (NCCT).
  • On NCCT:
  • blood in subarachnoid space would appear whiter compared to surrounding brain tissue
  • can also demonstrate significant mass effect and midline shift
  • These factors increase the severity of the underlying hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following increases the speed of induction with an inhalational agent?
questions.solution: • The speed of induction with an inhalational agent is increased by increased alveolar ventilation.

questions.text: Following accidental intra-arterial injection of thiopentone, which of the following should not be done?
questions.solution:
• Accidental intra-arterial injection of thiopentone is treated by:
    • Immediate stopping of further injection
    • Leave needle at site
    • Injection of heparin through the same needle
    • Injection of papaverine through the same needle (xylocaine can be used if papaverine is unavailable)
    • Brachial plexus/ stellate ganglion block - done to relieve vasospasm

questions.text: Which one of the following statements are NOT found in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
A.L.S presentation:

  • Weakness of extremities
  • Fasciculation of tongue
  • Decreased tone i.eHypotonia
  • Normal higher mental functions
  • No eye involvement-->No ptosis
  • Bulbar palsy : 9 /10 / 12th nerve palsy
  • No bladder / Bowel involvement
  • MCC of death in motor neuron disease: respiratory failure

questions.text: A 49 year old female presents to the OPD with complaints of anorexia, chronic cough, fever, Sputum: positive for Acid Fast Bacilli. Pick the accurate statement below regarding XDR-TB?

choices.text: Resistance to at least INH & rifampicin + any quinolones + at least 1 injectable 2nd line drug
Resistance to at least INH & rifampicin +/- other drugs
Resistance to any of the 3 first line drugs
Resistance to all 1st line drugs & any 3 second line injectable drugs

questions.solution:
XDR -TB: resistant to -

(a) INH & rifampicin

(b) Any fluoroquinolone

(c) 1 of 3 injectable drug (Amikacin, kanamycin or Capreomycin)

MDR-TB– Resistance to only INH & Rifampicin.

questions.text: A 7 year-old boy was treated for otitis media multiple times in the past year. Physical examination: mild lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, extensive crusted papules on skin. CT head: 4.2 cm osteolytic mass in mastoid bone. Biopsy of mass shown. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Langerhans cell histiocytosis:
    • Seen in children most often
    • Biopsy:
  • rodlike tubular Birbeck granules
  • characteristic periodicity seen in Langerhans cell proliferations
    • Multiple organ infiltrates:
  • skin eruptions
  • organomegaly
  • lesion in mastoid

    • Hand-Schüller-Christian disease: Exopthalmos + involvement of hypothalamus and pituitary stalk + diabetes insipidus

questions.text: An Enzyme deficiency leading to possible Basophilic stippling in RBCs is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Basophilic stippling: due to RNA residues in RBC, this occurs from a defect in Pyrimidine – 5 – Nucleotides
  • G6PD deficiency – Heinz bodies
  • Glutathione synthase – Antioxidants

questions.text: A 62 year old man with a 10 year progressive difficulty hearing, especially in left ear, shows bone conduction type of deafness on audiometric testing. CT head: no abnormal findings. The patient's brother, mother: similarly affected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Otosclerosis:
    • can be familial (especially if severe)
    • Due to fibrous ankylosis -> bony overgrowth of ear ossicles of middle ear.

questions.text: A 6 year-old girl presents to the OPD with difficulty breathing through her nose. On examination, she is diagnosed with adenoids. Which one of the following tonsils is most likely to be enlarged?
questions.solution:
• Enlarged pharyngeal tonsil: an adenoid.
  • Adenoid:
    • obstructs passage of air from nasal cavities --> through choanae --> into nasopharynx --> causes difficulty in nasal breathing and phonation.

questions.text: A 27 year old woman presents with complaints of Joint pain, photophobia, rash on her malar eminence. Which one of the following autoantibodies is most likely to be detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
- This patient appears to have SLE.

- Anti nuclear antibodies linked to SLE:

- Anti-Smith antibody

- anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibody

Anti-Rho or SS-A antibodies SLE, Sjogren syndrome (can be transmitted across the placenta resulting in neonatal lupus which presents as complete heart block)
U1 R.N.P. (Ribo-Nucleo-protein antibody). Mixed connective tissue
Anti ds-DNA antibody Increased risk of nephritis in cases of SLE.
Anti centromere antibody Limited scleroderma-CREST Syndrome
Antibodies to Ribosomal-P antigen CNS lupus
Antibodies to tRNA synthetase Polymyositis with interstitial lung disease
Anti - Glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody Latent autoimmune diabetes
Anti- Endomyosial antibody Celiac sprue
Anti-Histone antibody Drug induced lupus

questions.text: A 30 year-old woman has hoarseness in her voice, and her uvula is deviated to the left on phonation. Which of the following nerves is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
• Vagus nerve: innervates musculus uvulae
  • Lesion of the vagus nerve: causes deviation of the uvula toward the opposite side of the injury.
  • The patient's uvula is deviated to the left on phonation, the right vagus nerve is damaged.
  • - Hoarseness: caused by a paralysis of laryngeal muscles resulting from damage to skeletal motor fibers in the recurrent laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: The most characteristic clinical manifestation found in a patient with metabolic encephalopathy due to acute liver failure is which one of the following:
questions.solution:
-Metabolic encephalopathy → damage by ammonia or urea intoxication → contributes to anomic aphasia (difficulty in naming objects)

(Aka → Uremic / hepatic encephalopathy / CO2 narcosis)

  • Motor Aphasia: Broca’s area
  • Sensory Aphasia: Wernicke’s area
  • Conduction Aphasia: arcusfasciculus

questions.text: Collaural fistula is:
questions.solution:
• Abnormality of first branchial cleft
  • The fistula has two openings:
    • One: in neck just below and behind angle of mandible
    • Second: in external canal
  • The track of fistula → passes through parotid in close relation to facial nerve
  • Treatment: excision of tract

questions.text: All of the following are accurately matched except:

choices.text: Otolith – Made up of uric acid crystals
Position of otolith – Changes with head position
Otolith organs – Stimulated by gravity and linear acceleration

questions.solution: • Otolith: made up of calcium carbonate crystals

questions.text: The following matches are true regarding ECG appearances in electrolyte imbalances, EXCEPT:

choices.text: Hypokalemia-T wave becomes smaller, inverted and P wave width and amplitude decreased
Hyperkalemia-Tall tented T waves ,Broad complex QRS

questions.solution:
- Hypokalemia → P wave amplitude is raised

- ECG changes at K+ < 2.7 mmol/l:

  • Increased amplitude and width of the P wave
  • Apparentlong QT interval due to fusion of the T and U waves (long QU interval)
  • Prolongation of the PR interval
  • T wave flattening and inversion
  • ST depression
  • Prominent U waves (best seen in the precordial leads)

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral conductive deafness and tinnitus. He has a positive family history of the same. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Bilateral conductive deafness: rules out meniere’s disease (which presents with SNHL).
  • Positive family history is seen only with Otospongiosis/ Otosclerosis among the remaining 3 options.

questions.text: A 37 year -old man has a past medical history for scoliosis, which was surgically corrected at 14 years old. Family history: father and brother deaths with colon cancer at ages 46 and 52 years, respectively. Physical examination: tall stature, hypermobile joints, normal skin, ectopia lentis. Annual studies recommended to this patient?
questions.solution:
Marfan syndrome:

  • hypermobility and lens disorders suggest Marfan syndrome or, less commonly, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
  • high risk of aortic root disease in Marfan syndrome: echocardiography is indicated in this patient.

questions.text: After undergoing a laproscopic appendicectomy, a patient fell from her bed onto her nose. She subsequently developed swelling in nose with difficulty in breathing. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge after 2 days and follow up of the patient after 8 weeks

questions.solution:
• Septalhematoma:
    • Needs to drained as early as possible (<72 hours)
      • can lead to necrosis of septal cartilage
      • loss of support of dorsum
      • saddling of nose
      • infection and further septal abscess

questions.text: A 27 year old woman, with a history of Anorexia Nervosa for 7 years and a BMI of 19 kg/m2 presents with complaints of severe abdominal pain. The characteristic of Anorexia nervosa least likely to improve despite successful treatment is?
questions.solution: • Loss of bone mass: may not recover fully when AN occurs during adolescence (i.e., during peak bone mass formation).

questions.text: Which of the following is accurate about Gram staining?

choices.text: Heating: done to promote entry of stain into cell wall of Gram +ve and –ve bacteria
Gram +ve and –ve bacteria appear same staining technique and microscopy is observed prior to decolorization
Teichoic acid: present in cell wall of Gram–ve bacteria

questions.solution:
• In Gram stain:
    • Under decolorization: Everything looks gram-positive (violet)
    • Over decolorization: Everything looks gram-negative (pink)
  • Intermittent heating: done in acid fast stain (not gram stain)

questions.text: During an upper GI endoscopy performed in a TB suspect, reuse of the endoscope is possible after it is sterilized by?
questions.solution:
• Recommended disinfectants for endoscopes:
    • 2% Glutaraldehyde
    • Ophthaldehyde

questions.text: The medical triad of: hemolysis, pancytopenia and portal vein thrombosis is indicative of which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
?-? PNH:

- rare disorder

- stem cell–derived intracorpuscular defect

- characterized by:

-hemolytic anemia (particularly at night)

- venous thrombosis

- deficient hematopoiesis Both HUS and TTP cause hemolysis and thrombocytopenia, as well as fevers.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in the formation of peptide binding sites on MHC-I for the presenting of processed antigen to the CD8 T-cells?

choices.text: Junction of distal domains made-up of Alpha subunit
Junction of the proximal domains made-up of Alpha subunit
Junction of proximal domains made-up of beta subunit
Junction of distal Proximal domains made-up of beta subunit

questions.solution:
• Binding sites of MHC I & II molecules:
  • The antigen binding site:
    • For MHC I- groove between α1 and α2
    • For MHC II- groove between α1 and β1
    • Both these grooves lie in distal part of MHC molecules
  • The co-receptor binding site:
    • For MHC I- α3 domain binds to CD8 of Tc cell
    • For MHC II- β2 domain binds to CD4 of TH cell
    • Both these grooves lie in proximal part of MHC molecules.

questions.text: A 22 year old sexually active male presented to the OPD with a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans which released clear serum on pressure, after he had unprotected sexual intercourse with a sex worker. 15 days later: Inguinal lymph nodes on both groins were enlarged and non-tender. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

choices.text: Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge
Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.solution:
• Primary syphilis:
    • History of unprotected sexual intercourse with sex worker
    • Painless, indurated ulcer on glans
    • Enlarged and non-tender Inguinal lymph nodes
    • Diagnosis: Dark field microscopy of ulcer discharge

questions.text: A young male collapses after being hit in chest with a ball. V-fib present. Immediate defibrillation attempted, a normal sinus rhythm was restored. The patient is now stable. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Commotio cordis:
  • occurs due to blunt force injury to chest wall
  • results in fatal arrhythmia
  • frequently ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: In a patient who has a prosthetic valve replacement, there is development of endocarditis after 9 months. What would be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Staphylococcus Epidermidis:
    • MC CoNS— for 60–70% of CoNS
    • Produces polysaccharide glycocalyx (slime - Biofilm production
    • Adheres to any implanted foreign bodies - valvular shunts, prosthetic devices
    • Infections caused:
      • Endocarditis with the insertion of valvular prosthesis
      • Ventricular shunt infections and Stitch abscesses

questions.text: A 49 year old, HIV positive patient presents with cough, fever and dyspnea. The suspected cause of these symptoms would have all of the following, except?

choices.text: Perihilar diffuse infiltrates are seen in the early stage
ART effective against this causative organism

questions.solution:
• AIDS patient:

- common cause of infection is pneumococcus

- But pneumocystis jiroveci present only when CD4 is < 200.

- Antiretroviral therapy causes: a progressive decrease of P. jiroveci, however pneumococcus infection would still be present.

C/F:

- Shortness of breath

- Dyspnea

- Fever a/w chills & rigors

- Nonproductive cough

questions.text: A young man is presented to the ER with a left mid thigh crush injury. The most essential step in the prevention of gas gangrene in this patient is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Early surgical debridement: most crucial step in management of gas gangrene
  • Done for removal of all devitalised tissues to remove conditions that produce anaerobiosis.

questions.text: Which one of the following would be present in a patient who presents with diarrhea due to Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
• Clinical features: Cholera
    • Sudden onset painless voluminous watery diarrhea
    • Fever: usually absent
    • Mild neutrophilic Leukocytosis
    • Non invasive diarrhea (no pus cells in stool)

questions.text: A middle aged male, known case of diabetes mellitus, developed cirrhosis, with associated skin hyperpigmentation + restrictive cardiomyopathy. Best initial test for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
- Work up in patient of hemochromatosis:

A)

  • Serum Iron: ↑↑
  • TIBC: ↑↑
  • Percentage saturation of Transferrin: ↑↑
  • Serum Ferritin: ↑ = >1000-6000 micro gm/dl
  • IOC: Liver Biopsy with estimation of Iron content
  • Hepatic Iron index > 2

B) HbA1C

C) Echo

D) X-ray hand

E) USG liver (Hepatomegaly and Liver cirrhosis)

questions.text: A baby is delivered with visible scarring of skin and deformity of limbs. Which one of the following intrauterine infections is responsible in this case?
questions.solution:
• Fetal Varicella syndrome: characterized by
    • Cicatrization skin lesion
    • Chorioretinitis
    • CNS defects
    • Limb hypoplasia

questions.text: A woman presented with secondary amenorrhoea for 4 years along with galactorrhea. Most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
- Causes of IGT:

  • Glucagonoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Cushing Syndrome
  • Acromegaly

Causes of Galactorrhea

  • Prolactinoma
  • CKD
  • Drug – Antipsychotics
  • 1° Hypothyroidism
  • Agromegaly

questions.text: A perimenopausal woman presented with a 5-week history of greenish discharge from her left nipple. On examination, the left nipple has a ‘slit-like’ appearance, is retracted and non-tender. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
- This presentation is typical of mammary duct ectasia, which is common in perimenopausal women. - Nipple discharge:

  • ranges from milky, brown to a dirty green colour
  • Bilateral
  • associated with cyclical mastalgia.

- Nipple retraction can cause suspicion of breast carcinoma.

- Presence of slit in the nipple, along with colour of the nipple discharge and perimenopausal age of patient: more likely to be duct ectasia.

questions.text: A 26 years old male presents with a 4 month history of loose stools with weight loss. He tests positive for HIV. The presence of which one of the following diseases is most likely in the diagnosis of HIV?
questions.solution:
• Acute HIV Syndrome: presents as acute infectious mononucleosis/ glandular fever like syndrome, which is characterized by:
    • General:
      • Fever
      • Pharyngitis
      • Lymphadenopathy
      • Headache
      • arthralgia/myalgia
      • weight loss
      • vomiting/diarrhea
    • Neurologic:
      • Meningitis
      • Encephalitis
      • peripheral neuropathy
      • Myelopathy
    • Dermatologic:
      • Rash
      • mucocutaneous ulceration

questions.text: Multiple duodenal ulcers not amenable to conventional medical therapy are associated with which one of the following syndromes listed below?
questions.solution:
- Zollinger–Ellison syndrome:

  • non-insulin secreting tumour of the pancreas
  • releases high levels of gastrin-like hormone
  • causes hyperacidity of stomach
  • Predisposes to severe and extensive duodenal ulceration

questions.text: The most appropriate investigation for the quick diagnosis of an aortic dissection is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
- CT scan:

  • rapid diagnosis of an aortic dissection

-MRI: a greater sensitivity.

questions.text: A child, who has recently moved from Bihar, presented to the OPD with fever. Blood examination: sheathed microfilaria with nuclei up to tail tip. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Microfilaria with nuclei up to tail tip:
    • B. malayi
    • B. timori
    • Loa loa (Restricted to Africa {African eye worm})
    • M.perstans
    • M.streptocerca
  • Microfilaria with tail tip free from nuclei:
    • W. bancrofti
    • M. ozzardi
    • Onchocerca volvulus
  • Since Loa loa is by location (the child is from Bihar), B. malayi is the appropriate option here.

questions.text: In a patient who has recently undergone a cardiopulmonary bypass surgery, AKI evaluation is done. One of the following urine microscopy findings suggests cholesterol emboli, which is the source of renal failure?
questions.solution:
- Cholesterol emboli:

  • cause of AKI in cardiac surgery patients
  • Especially with atherosclerotic disease
  • Atherosclerotic plaques: may get disrupted and shower (aka: cholesterol emboli)

questions.text: In repair of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, the following is not true about drainage of subretinal fluid:

choices.text: drainage is indicated if there is significant vitreoretinal traction
drainage should be performed before buckling.
it can help to localise the retinal hole
it is useful for softening the eye

questions.solution:
• The indications for drainage of subretinal fluid are:
  • presence of a bullous retinal detachment which is making localisation of a retinal tear or hole difficult
  • long-standing retinal detachment with viscous subretinal fluid; and inferior retinal detachment.
    • Drainage should be performed before buckling and away from the retina break (use of cryotherapy at site of drainage may cause problems).

questions.text: A young woman experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She has no identifying information on herself , her past medical history is unknown. Most likely cause of her seizure?
questions.solution:
- Adolescence and early adulthood:

- period where idiopathic or genetic epilepsy syndromes become less common

- seizures due to acquired CNS lesions become more common.

- MCC of seizures in the young adults:

- head trauma

- CNS infections

- brain tumors

- congenital CNS lesions

- illicit drug use - alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A young male presents with a history of episodic abdominal pain, stress-induced edema of lips. The tongue will possibly have low functional or absolute levels of which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary Angioedema:
  • Treatment of choice in acute attacks: replacement with Cl inhibitor (C l-IN H) concentrates/ kallikrein inhibitor or, if unavailable, fresh-frozen plasma.

questions.text: Which one of the following pairs are incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Gerstmann's syndrome:
    • lesion in dominant parietal lobe
    • Characterized by:
      • acalculia
      • agraphia
      • finger agnosia
      • left-right confusion
  • Prosopagnosia:
    • inability to recognise familiar faces
    • results from bilateral occipitotemporal involvement
  • Achromatopsia:
    • abnormal colour discrimination
    • arises from bilateral parietal or occipital lobe abnormalities.
  • Akinetopsia:
    • insensitivity to motion
    • results from lesion in middle temporal gyrus.

questions.text: Regarding the Nipah virus, all of the following are incorrect except:
questions.solution:
• Host: Man
  • Intermittent host: Pig
  • Source:

- Fruit contaminated with dropping/ saliva of Pteropus/ Flying fox/ Bat

  • Mode of transmission

- Sap date palm

- Fruits

- Closed personal contact

  • No vaccine or treatment
  • Potential Category 3 bio weapon

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about ocular symptoms caused by vitamin B12 deficiency?

choices.text: produces a decrease in central vision with relative sparing of peripheral vIsion
causes temporal pallor of the optic nerve in long-standing cases

questions.solution:
• Vitamin B12 deficiency:
    • may lead to optic neuropathy
    • Colour vision —> affected
    • Visual field —> central or centrocecal scotoma
    • Posterior pole —> flame-shaped and dot-blot retinal haemorrhages
    • Temporal pallor of optic nerve —> commonly seen
    • Is a cause of amblyopia in alcohol-tobacco amblyopia.

questions.text: Amblyopia is best corrected by:
questions.solution: • Amblyopia: usually corrected best within 8 years of age.

questions.text: A young man presents with blurred vision in the right eye followed by the left eye within 4 months. The optic disc appears to be edematous, hyperemic and with circumpapillary telangiectasia, and centrocecal scotoma on perimetry. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON):
    • Mitochondrial DNA mutation (maternal inheritance)
    • Males 15-35 y/o
    • Unilateral papillitis —> other eye affected in few weeks
    • Optic disc:
      • Hyperemic
      • Edematous
      • Telangiectatic microangiopathy
    • Prognosis: poor
    • Optic atrophy development seen
    • Inj. Vit B12 + Steroids given

questions.text: A 32 year old man, with 6/5 unaided vision in each eye, complains of blurring of newsprints at 30 cm which clears up in approximately 2 minutes. His cyclopegic refraction is 0.00. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Accommodative inertia:
    • The patient has good distance and near vision
    • has difficulty in adjusting from one distance to another

questions.text: Which one of the following will not cause a hazy cornea in a newborn child?
questions.solution:
• Hazy cornea in a child (STUMPED)
  • S- Sclerocornea
  • T- Trauma during birth
  • U- Ulcer
  • M- Mucopolysaccharidosis
  • P- Peter's anomaly
  • E- Endothelial dystrophy
  • D- Dermoid (limbal)
    • Also Congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: One of the following is used to prevent a recurrence after a pterygium excision.
questions.solution:
• Bare sclera technique of pterygium excision: high chance of recurrence
  • Techniques used to prevent this recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C
    • Amniotic membrane graft
    • Conjunctival autograft

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement:

choices.text: Acidic drugs: bind to albumin in the plasma
Basic drugs: bind to alpha-1 acid glycoprotein in the plasma
Drugs having higher affinity for plasma protein: can displace other drug from same protein
Sex steroid hormones: do not bind to any protein in the plasma

questions.solution:
• Acidic drugs: bind mainly to albumin

Basic drugs: bind to alpha-1 acid glycoprotein.
Drugs having high PPB: (sulfonamides) displace other drugs bound to same site; may result in toxicity.

  • Sex steroids: bind to the steroid hormone binding globulin, along with albumin.

questions.text: The most common microsomal enzyme involved in metabolism of xenobiotics is:
questions.solution: • CYP 3A4: most common microsomal enzyme in xenobiotic metabolism

questions.text: A drug that competes with ACh for receptors at the motor end plate affect skeletal muscle in which of the following ways?

choices.text: Causes muscles to contract and be unable to relax
Causes muscles to contract and be unable to relax
Causes muscles to contract and be unable to relax

questions.solution:
• Drugs competing with Ach at neuromuscular junctions are competitive or non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers.
  • These drugs: used as muscle relaxants and do not cause initial fasciculations (unlike depolarizing muscle relaxants).

questions.text: Tarnsulosin, a competitive alpha-adrenoceptor antagonist, has affinity for which of the following receptors?
questions.solution: • Tamsulosin has an affinity to Alpha-1A adrenoreceptors.

questions.text: A 35 years old female presents with a diffuse thyroid swelling. On investigations: TSH levels were elevated. Postoperative HPE reports: intense lymphocytic infiltration and Hu?rthle cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• History highly suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis:
  • diffuse thyroid swelling in a female
  • hypothyroid (raised TSH levels)
  • HPE: intense lymphocytic infiltration (and plasma cells)
  • Hu?rthle cells: abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm

questions.text: A 7 years old child has a history of acute liver failure. Which of the following criteria is not included in the King’s college criteria?

choices.text: Jaundice <7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.solution:
- King’s College Criteria Associated with Poor Prognosis for Acute Liver Failure (ALF) Patients:

→ Patients with Non–Acetaminophen-Induced ALF:

- INR >6.5Q OR

- Three of the following five criteria:

  • Patient age <11 or >40 years
  • Serum bilirubin >300 μmol/L
  • Time from onset of jaundice to development of coma >7 days
  • INR >3.5
  • Drug toxicity, regardless of whether it caused ALF

→ Patients with Acetaminophen-Induced ALF:

- Arterial pH <7.3 (taken by arterial blood sampling)

- All three of the following:

  • INR >6.5Q
  • Serum creatinine >300 μmol/LQ
  • Presence of encephalopathyQ (grade III or IV)

questions.text: A young man, who met with a bike accident, had injury to ileum and jejunum. The entire ileum and part of the jejunum was resected. Which one of the following would the patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
- Short Bowel Syndrome:

→ Patients with resection of even 100-200 cm of jejunum anastomosed to an intact colon may be at risk of:

- Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency

- B12 vitamin deficiency

→ These patients may require:

- Oral supplements of vitamins, minerals, trace elements

questions.text: An 84 years old female presented with colicky pain and jaundice. Serum bilirubin and GGT: raised. MRCP image: gallstones, CBD stones with dilated biliary radicles. Most appropriate next step in the management:
questions.solution:
- ERCP is indicated in patients with obstructive jaundice when: endoscopic intervention is expected based on prior imaging. -

Done for:

→ Endoscopic removal of CBD stones

→ Biliary drainage in septic patient

→ Insertion of biliary tract stent

questions.text: The contraindication for radical mastectomy in CA breast:
Gynaecomastia may be seen in all of the patients except:
questions.solution: - Gynecomastia is NOT seen in patients with Turner’s syndrome.

questions.text: An infant is diagnosed with the MEN-2B trait. Which one of the following will be the best possible line of management?
questions.solution:
- Prophylactic Thyroidectomy in RET Mutation Carriers:

→ MEN 2A: Before 5 years

→ MEN 2B: Before 1 year

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for percutaneous aspiration in amebic liver abscess?

choices.text: Compression or outflow obstruction of hepatic or portal vein

questions.solution:
- Amoebic Liver Abscess:

→ Clinical improvement after adequate treatment with antiamebic agents is the rule

→ Radiologic resolution of the abscess cavity: usually delayed

  • The average time to radiologic resolution is 3 to 9 months (years in some patients)
  • > 90% of visible lesions disappear radiologically
  • Small percentage of patients: left with a clinically irrelevant residual lesion

questions.text: In a patient with compensated liver cirrhosis presented with history of variceal bleed. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution: - Management of variceal bleeding:

questions.text: Gallbladder stone formation is influenced by all except:
questions.solution:
- Hyperalimentation decreases GB motility and promotes stasis and Gallstone formation.

- Primary biliary cirrhosis decreases bile salt secretion in bile.

- Clofibrate therapy increases biliary cholesterol.

questions.text: Acute pancreatitis is associated with all except:
questions.solution: - Steatorrhea is seen with CHRONIC pancreatitis, not acute.

questions.text: Which of the following defines Rossetti modification of Nissen’s fundoplication?

choices.text: Excludes the stomach wall in the wrap
Include only the posterior stomach wall in the wrap
Include only the anterior stomach wall in the wrap
Include both the anterior and the posterior stomach wall in the wrap

questions.solution:
→ Nissen’s fundoplication:

- Left crus approach to a 360-degree wrap (Nissenfundoplication): procedure of choice for GERD

questions.text: Person wakes up with pain, paresthesia, tingling of the arms. He had slept with arm below his head. Which fibers are involved?

questions.text: For cerebral blood flow to be doubled, pCO2 should be:

questions.text: Toxic effects of high oxygen tension include all of the following except:

  • Some infants treated with O2 develop bronchopulmonary dysplasia, retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia). It can also lead to muscle twitching, ringing in the ears, dizziness, convulsions, and coma.
  • 100% oxygen inhalation causes arterial vasoconstriction with an associated small (10%–15%) reduction in cerebral blood flow (CBF).

questions.text: A young primigravida with a twin gestation at 31 weeks presents for a USG.The USG indicates: fetuses are both male, placenta - diamniotic and monochorionic.Twin B: oligohydramnios, much smaller than twin A. All of the following would be medical concerns for twin A except:
questions.solution:
→ Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)

  • Always seen in monochorionic placenta
  • M/C in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy > monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy
  • Arteriovenous malformation from umbilical arterial system of “donor” twin to umbilical vein of the “recipient” twin
  • Donor twin: growth restricted, hypovolemic, oligohydramnios and anemic (as it gives blood to the recipient twin)
  • Recipient twin: larger, hypervolemic, polyhydramnios and plethoric
  • The earlier the TTTS appears - worse will be the prognosis
  • More common in female fetuses
  • In the question — Twin A: recipient twin, Twin B: donor twin (oligohydramnios)

questions.text: A 38 year-old woman with chronic CHF for the past 4 years, has developed a cough productive of rust-colored sputum in the last 3 months. questions.text: A 49 year-old man presents with an episode of chest pain for 6 hours. Histologic section of the left ventricular myocardium is given in the image below. No hemorrhage/ inflammation. Which of the following most likely causes these myocardial changes in this patient?

questions.text: All of the following are features of Noonan syndrome, EXCEPT ?

- The majority of gastrinomas are malignant.

questions.text: The parents of a 3year old male child state that the child has cheese-like, white material occurring from his foreskin, and he cannot fully retract the foreskin behind the glans penis. What would be the correct management in this case?

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding a situation in which a bat is found in the bedroom of a 5 year old sleeping boy? The family and the patient himself denies any bites or contact with the bat.

choices.text: Therapy only if patient has signs of rabies infection.

questions.solution:

  • Other potential vectors: skunks, bats, foxes, and coyotes.
  • The CDC recommends that postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) even without an obvious bat bite.
  • PEP consists of:
  • wound cleansing (if there is a wound)
  • rabies immune globulin (RIG)
  • five injection rabies vaccine series

questions.text: 15 year old girl presented with complaints of menorrhagia. History revealed, A previously diagnosed case of von-Willebrands disease. True about VWD ?

choices.text: Isolated prolonged aPTT with a normal PT
Isolated prolonged PT with a normal aPTT
Prolongation of both PT and aPTT

questions.solution:
• Von Willebrand factor acts as a plasma carrier of factor VIII and circulates in blood as factor VIII-VWF complex.
  • Thus, VWF deficiency impairs intrinsic pathway of coagulation & prolongs aPTT
  • Extrinsic pathway of coagulation remains unimpaired, so PT is not altered.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is diagnosed with ALL. Which of the following cytogenetic changes would show a good prognosis?

- t(9;22), t(1;19), 11q23 rearrangements, and hypodiploidy are all associated with poor prognosis in these leukemias.

- The 9;22 translocation seen in ALL is cytogenetically identical but molecularly distinct from the one typically seen in CML.

questions.text: A 22 year old man comes to OPD with severe back pain, fever and unintentional weight loss for the past month. On a physical exam, he has a kyphotic deformity present on his back. What is not true about the management of Pott’s paraplegia?

choices.text: Paraplegia not improving with conservative treatment even after 3–6 weeks is an indication for operative intervention

Chemotherapy is the mainstay of conservative management
Decompression via anterolateral approach is most preferred

questions.solution:

Management of Pott’s paraplegia:

questions.text: A child was brought to hospital with the complaint of swollen hand after a fall. X ray was taken and the image is given below. What is the age of this patient?
questions.solution:

  • Distal: Trapezium Trapezoid, capitate, Hamate
  • Capitate: Central, Largest ,oldest bone
  • Pisiform: Youngest bone
  • Carpal bones start to ossify after birth
  • Capitate starts to ossify at 2nd month
  • Hamate states to ossify at 3rd month
  • Triquetrum starts to ossify at 3rd year
  • Lunate state to ossify at 4th year
  • Scaphoid, Trapezium, trapezoid ossified at 5th year
  • Pisiform: 9 to 12 years
  • In the given image capitate, hamate and Triquetrum are seen. So minimum age of the person is 3 years and maximum age is 4 years.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about free energy change of a reaction?

choices.text: if negative —> enables the reaction to occur spontaneously.
if positive —> enables the reaction to occur spontaneously.
is greater than zero when the reaction is at equilibrium.
determines the rate at which a reaction will attain equilibrium.

questions.solution:
If the free energy change of a reaction is negative, the reaction is likely to occur spontaneously.

GIBBS Free Energy change/ Free energy change

  • It is quantity of energy which is a measure of maximum amount of work that can be done by a system at constant temperature and pressure.
  • It is zero at equilibrium
  • It does not determine the rate of attainment of equilibrium.
  • It just determine if reaction will occur spontaneous or not.

questions.text: Which one of the following components of the electron transport chain only accepts electrons, and does not donate them?
questions.solution:
• Under normal physiological conditions oxygen is the terminal electron acceptor in electron transport chain during an aerobic respiration.
  • It will accept electron and form H2O by reduction by enzyme cytochrome c oxidase.
  • Now the water formed on reduction cannot donate its electrons further to the other substrates.
  • So we can say that O2 has highest reduction potential in the ETC.

questions.text: The biochemical allosteric effect of CTP on ATCase is known as:
questions.solution:
Heterotropic allosteric regulation: Its a type of regulation where regulatory molecule is not the target enzyme's substrate but would still cause its inhibition. e.g. H+, CO2, 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate are heterotropic allosteric modulators of Hb

Homotropic allosteric regulation: Here regulatory molecule is a substrate for its target protein and is usually an activator of the protein.

Cytidine triphosphate, an end product of the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, inhibits aspartate transcarbamoylase despite having little structural similarity to its reactants or products.

It is believed that CTP and UTP inhibit ATCase by weakening the R state; conversely, ATP and GTP activate ATCase by strengthening the R state.0

questions.text: In normal conditions in blood, which one of the following amino acid residues of albumin is neutral?
questions.solution:
In blood and other solutions at physiologic pH (~ 7), only the following amino acid residues in proteins have charges:

  • terminal carboxyl groups
  • terminal amino groups
  • ionizable side chains

- Basic amino acids lysine, arginine, histidinehave positive charges due to their protonated amine form.

- Acidic amino acids (aspartate and glutamate) have negative charges, due to ionized carboxyl groups

Glutamine due to absence of any of ionizable groups in side chain will be uncharged

questions.text: Which one of the following regulates lipolysis in adipocytes under fasting/starvation conditions?

choices.text: Activation of fatty acid synthesis mediated by cyclic AMP
Activation of Hormone sensitive lipase after hormone stimulated increases in cAMP levels
Activation of cyclic AMP production by insulin

questions.solution:
Under fasting/starvation, Glucagon and other catabolic hormones such as Epinephrine

  • stimulates adenylate cyclase that will produces cyclic AMP that in turn activateprotein kinase by phosphphorylation toactivate HSL.
  • HSL present in the adipose tissue then causes lipolysis of stored triglyceride to release free fatty acids and glycerol in blood.

questions.text: About the inheritance of Ehler Danlos syndrome, which subtype is inherited in an X linked recessive manner?

Ehler -Danlos Syndrome

Enzyme deficiency are:

questions.text: Multiple sclerosis is best described as which of the following?

A Lipid storage disease - accumulation of sphingolipids in brain
A Lipid storage disease - loss of sphingolipids, gangliosides from brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: A homeless young male is brought to the ER with psychotic imagery and the smell of alcohol on his breath. Which of the following compounds is most important to administer?

questions.text: All of the below mentioned statements are accurate about skeletal imaging, except?

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following reagents would be required to perform an immunochemical screen of a bacterial population of bacteria for the presence of a particular cloned gene if you have the pure protein encoded by the gene?

choices.text: radioactive antibody to protein encoded by cloned gene

questions.solution:
Immunochemical screen is a process of utilizing the property of extreme specificity of an antibody for its antigen. It can be done to detect a particular protein in a bacteria by western blotting techniques.

Done by adding radioactive antibody to lysed bacterial colonies and examining population by autoradiography

Done to see: which colonies contain antigen (protein) due to gene insertion and expression of protein of interest.

Option B- Polynucleotide kinase is used to add gamma-phosphate from ATP to the 5'-OH group of single- and double-stranded DNAs and RNAs, oligonucleotides, or nucleoside 3'-monophosphates for ligation reactions in cloning.

Option C- DNA polymerase is used to synthesize DNA using PCR

Option A- [Gamma-32P]ATP is also used to label DNA or RNA again useful for ligation reactions.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman with a 6 year history of psoriasis (involving her elbows) has been on topical glucocorticoids and a vitamin D analogue. In the past 9 months, her psoriasis has worsened. She now has developed new lesions on her knees, gluteal regions, and scalp, as well as swelling of her digits with pain and stiffness. There is no systemic infection. All of the following therapies will worsen widespread psoriatic disease EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate: effective in patients with psoriatic arthritis
  • Cyclosporine: effective in psoriasis
  • Alefacept is an intramuscular biologic: indicated in psoriasis.
  • However, these are all associated with an increased risk of serious systemic infection, neurologic events, and hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman is started on glyburide 10mg sustained release tablets OD for type 2 diabetes mellitus. She develops an erythematous rash, after spending an afternoon in the garden. Which of the following features cause a suspicion of photoallergy over phototoxicity?

choices.text: Persistent hypersensitivity to light after cessation of drug

questions.solution:
• Sulfonylurea medications: cause both photoallergy and phototoxicity reactions
  • Phototoxicity: nonimmunologic reaction that occurs without a latency period after drug ingestion. Like a sunburn, a phototoxic reaction blisters and desquamates.
  • Photoallergic reaction: occurs when UV rays transform drug into an unstable hapten capable of stimulating an immune response (delayed hypersensitivity that is intensely pruritic), the sun-exposed areas appear lichenified and leathery. This phenomenon continues even after the cessation of sulfonylureas.

questions.text: On physical examination of a 2-day-old neonate: multiple blisters on trunk and extremities. Skin biopsy: separation of basal layer of epidermis from basement membrane, no inflammatory cells. Immunofluorescence microscopy: No antibody deposits. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

  • tendency to form blisters at sites of minor trauma
  • mutations of genes encoding cytokeratin intermediate filaments
  • cosmetically disturbing and sometimes debilitating, but not life threatening.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about sunburn is true?

choices.text: UV B radiation causes maximum development of sunburn at midday.
Red haired and fair skinned: have high activity of melanocortin-1 receptor
UVB: more effective at causing sunburn erythema than UVA
Lag time from sun exposure to development of visible redness: 1–2 hours.

questions.solution:
• Sunburn: acute inflammatory reaction of skin to sunlight, mostly due to the UVB radiation.
  • Sunburn erythema: due to vasodilation of dermal blood vessels
  • Lag time of 4–12 hours after sun exposure to development of visible redness.

questions.text: A 70 year old woman presents with a pruritic vulvar lesion. Physical examination reveals an irregular white, rough area involving her vulva. If this area of leukoplakia is due to lichen sclerosis, then biopsies from this area will most likely reveal:

choices.text: Atrophy of epidermis with dermal fibrosis
Loss of pigment in the epidermis

questions.solution:
• Lichen sclerosis is seen histologically as atrophy of the epidermis with underlying dermal fibrosis.
  • This abnormality is seen in postmenopausal women, who develop pruritic white plaques of the vulva.
  • It is not thought to be premalignant.
  • Loss of pigment in the epidermis (vitiligo) can also produce leukoplakia.
